children.subject:
CS 281A is actually not a recommended course if you want to research in ML because it is too introductory. The ML courses that graduate students usually take are Stat 210A/B and EE 227B/C. In some semesters, there are also relevant courses like EE 290.

Math 128A/B might indeed help with ML because iterative methods like gradient descent and Newton's method are originally research subjects of numerical analysis, so in this regard, Math 221 might also be interesting to you.

I think Math 113 and 185 might be too abstract to be useful in ML research. You should avoid them if your time is limited.

Disagree with student answer. 113 is almost useless for ML, but is an interesting math class since if you need an extra upper-div elective I would recommend 113 (although you can check out the research Professor Sturmfels is doing so I might be wrong in the future). Math 185 I would recommend anybody to take if you've suffered through 104, since 185 is the reward; the theorem's introduced in the class are quite astounding compared to the annoying counter examples found in real analysis, but so far the residue theorem or Laurent series expnasion haven't really helped me out in my research yet. Some people will recommend measure theoretic probability if you're more interested in the probability side, so Math 105/202A and Stat 205A are also good choices.

Echoing the other followup, I don't think 281 is that helpful for doing research, and your time would be better suited taking 210A/B or 227B/C. In fact I would say, depending on what direction you want to go within ML, 210A/B or 227B/C form the core courses for content and no other courses are quite as important as them (other than, of course, fundamental courses like 104/126/127). 

As for the numerical analysis courses, they may be helpful if you're interested in the computation side of ML but not so much if you're interested in the theory side.

history.content:
Apart from Math 104, Math 110, EE126/127, and 189, what math and stats classes are recommended to pursue ML (for PhD)? 

I want to take 281A/B, but I want to enroll in other math/stats classes as well in case I cannot get in.
history.subject: Math for ML Path
